newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil oil bill still faces bickering - ministry.
newsitem.headline: Brazil oil bill still faces bickering - ministry.

text.p: A bill to regulate the opening up of Brazil's oil industry to private competition remains grid-locked in bickering between Congress and the government, an official said on Tuesday.

Giovanni Toniatti, secretary of mines and minerals at the Mines and Energy Ministry, told Reuters Congress was making "unrealistic" demands that a regulatory body for the industry be totally independent.

Congress last year voted to end state-owned Petrobras' monopoly of the sector but a bill setting up the regulatory framework for the oil industry, initially expected to be voted on this summer, has been delayed.
"The controversy continues," Toniatti said. "Congress wants something that doesn't exist anywhere in the world, a totally independent regulator."

Last month Dep. Eliseu Resende, who was appointed to draft a new version of the regulatory bill after the original faced criticism for offering too many privileges to Petrobras, said he expected to present his bill to Congress in November.
Resende said then his bill would reduce the Petrobras bias and give more power to the regulator, the National Petroleum Agency.

Toniatti, speaking at an international seminar in Brasilia on the oil and minerals sector, said he was confident Brazil faced a "rapid period of transition" despite disagreements between Congress and the government.
